com.apriori.reflect

Class MethodCapturer<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.apriori.reflect.MethodCapturer<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the interface whose methods are captured or Object if methods from multiple interfaces are captured

    public class MethodCapturer<E>
extends Object
    A mechanism for capturing Java method calls. This is useful to lookup instances of java.lang.reflect.Method and MethodSignature with compile-time type and method checking instead of relying only on runtime lookup/checking with a String and array of argument types.
    See Also:
    capture()

      • MethodCapturer

        public MethodCapturer(Class<E> iface)
        Constructs a new object for capturing methods for one interface.
        Parameters:
        iface - The class token for the interface whose methods will be captured
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified class token does not represent an interface
        NullPointerException - if the specified class token is null

      • MethodCapturer

        @SafeVarargs
public MethodCapturer(Class<? extends E>... interfaces)
        Constructs a new object for capturing methods for one or more interfaces.
        Parameters:
        interfaces - The class tokens for the interfaces whose methods will be captured
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if no interfaces are specified, if any of the specified class tokens does not represent an interface, if the interfaces are incompatible (they have a method with the same signature but different and incompatible return types), or if a proxy object for the interfaces cannot be created using the ClassLoader of any of the interfaces
        NullPointerException - if any of the specified class tokens is null

      • MethodCapturer

        public MethodCapturer(Set<Class<? extends E>> interfaces)
        Constructs a new object for capturing methods for one or more interfaces.
        Parameters:
        interfaces - The set of class tokens for the interfaces whose methods will be captured
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if no interfaces are specified, if any of the specified class tokens does not represent an interface, if the interfaces are incompatible (they have a method with the same signature but different and incompatible return types), or if a proxy object for the interfaces cannot be created using the ClassLoader of any of the interfaces
        NullPointerException - if any of the specified class tokens is null

    • Method Detail

      • getInterfaces

        public Set<Class<? extends E>> getInterfaces()
        Returns the set of interfaces whose methods can be captured. If only a single interface's methods are captured then this returns a singleton set with just Class<E>.
        Returns:
        set of interfaces whose methods can be captured

      • capture

        public E capture()
        Returns a proxy for the interfaces whose methods are captured. Invoking a method on the returned object will "capture" the method call. Subsequent calls to getMethod() or getSignature() will return the method called. Invoking the method does nothing else (no real implementation) and will return null (or zero for numeric primitive return types; false for boolean primitive return type). So parameters passed to the method can all be null. The method invocation just lets the compiler verify that the method is valid and lets client programs access it as a java.lang.Method or MethodSignature without runtime lookups.

        Note that multiple calls to this method all return the same object and do not in any way "reset" the last captured method. Also note that multiple calls to this proxy do not in any way "queue" the captured methods. The getMethod() and getSignature() methods always return the last method called.

        Take the following example of the wrong way to use the capturer. 

         MethodCapturer<MyInterface> capturer =
       new MethodCapturer<MyInterface>(MyInterface.class);
 MyInterface i = capturer.capture();
 
 // call some methods
 i.someMethod();
 i.someOtherMethod(null, null);
 i.yetAnotherMethod(null);
 
 // get the method objects
 Method m1 = capturer.getMethod();
 Method m2 = capturer.getMethod();
 Method m3 = capturer.getMethod();
        All returned methods -- m1, m2, and m3 -- will be the same object and will correspond to MyInterface.yetAnotherMethod. The correct usage follows: 
         i.someMethod();
 Method m1 = capturer.getMethod();
 
 i.someOtherMethod(null, null);
 Method m2 = capturer.getMethod();
 
 i.yetAnotherMethod(null);
 Method m3 = capturer.getMethod();
        For methods that return values (vs. just those that return void), you can use the following syntax to make this even more readable: 
         Method m1 = capturer.getMethod(i.someMethod());
 Method m2 = capturer.getMethod(i.someOtherMethod(null, null));
 Method m3 = capturer.getMethod(i.yetAnotherMethod(null));
        Returns:
        a proxy that captures method calls
        See Also:
        getMethod(), getMethod(Object)

      • getMethod

        public Method getMethod()
        Returns the last method captured. If no method has ever been called on the proxy (accessible from capture()) then this will return null.
        Returns:
        the last method called on the proxy

      • getMethod

        public Method getMethod(Object o)
        Returns the last method captured. The argument is a dummy argument and is meant to provide "syntactic sugar" to enhance readability.

        Take the following example: 

         i.someMethod();
 Method m = capturer.getMethod();
        This could instead be written as follows to enhance readability: 
         Method m = capturer.getMethod(i.someMethod());

        Note that you will not be able to use this "sugar" for methods that return void and will have to use the first form shown above.

        Parameters:
        o - dummy argument that isn't used but should be an expression that calls a single method on the proxy interface, like in the example above
        Returns:
        the last method called on the proxy

      • getSignature

        public MethodSignature getSignature()
        Returns the signature of the last method captured. If no method has ever been called on the proxy (accessible from capture()) then this will return null.
        Returns:
        the signature of the last method called on the proxy

      • getSignature

        public MethodSignature getSignature(Object o)
        Returns the last method captured. The argument is a dummy argument and is meant to provide "syntactic sugar" to enhance readability. See getMethod(Object) for examples.
        Parameters:
        o - dummy argument that isn't used but should be an expression that calls a single method on the proxy interface for improved readability
        Returns:
        the last method called on the proxy
